natural problem:
Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.)
natural solution: So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.

These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "m = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..<fact 4}. if coprime i (fact 4) then i else 1)"
shows  "m (fact 4) mod fact 4 = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "m = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..<fact 4}. if coprime i (fact 4) then i else 1)"
shows  "m (fact 4) mod fact 4 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let m be a function that takes an integer and returns the product of all integers less than the factorial of 4, where each integer in the product is included only if it is coprime with the factorial of 4. What is the remainder when the factorial of 4 is divided by m? The final answer is 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod (\<lambda>x. x) {x. x \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> coprime x (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod (\<lambda>x. x) {x. x \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> coprime x (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Calculate the product of all numbers less than 4 factorial that are coprime with 4 factorial. What is the remainder when this product is divided by 4 factorial? The answer is 1.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. fact n = prod {1..n}"
and h1 : "m = prod {x \<in> {1..(fact 4 - 1)}. [x = 1] (mod fact 4)}"
shows  "[m = 1] (mod fact 4)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. fact n = prod {1..n}"
and h1 : "m = prod {x \<in> {1..(fact 4 - 1)}. [x = 1] (mod fact 4)}"
shows  "[m = 1] (mod fact 4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Assume that the factorial function is defined as the product of all positive integers up to its argument. Let $m$ be the product of the set of numbers $x$ such that $x$ is in the set of positive integers up to $4!-1$ and $x$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $4!$. Show that $m$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $4!$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m n :: nat
assumes h0 : "m = prod (\<lambda>i. i mod fact 4) {i \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime i (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m n :: nat
assumes h0 : "m = prod (\<lambda>i. i mod fact 4) {i \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime i (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Let $m$ be the product of the remainders when each natural number $i$ from $1$ to $4! - 1$ (inclusive) that is coprime to $4!$ is divided by $4!$. What is the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$? The answer is $1$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. fact n = prod {1..n}"
and h1 : "m = prod {i \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime i (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. fact n = prod {1..n}"
and h1 : "m = prod {i \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime i (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the product of all integers less than $4! = 24$ that are relatively prime to 24 (in other words, their greatest common divisor with 24 is 1). What is the remainder when this product is divided by 24? The final answer is 1.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. n \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> gcd n (fact 4) = 1}"
shows  "m mod (fact 4) = 1"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. n \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> gcd n (fact 4) = 1}"
shows  "m mod (fact 4) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let $m$ be the product of all integers from 1 to $4!$ (i.e., 24) that are relatively prime to $4!$. What is the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$? The final answer is 1.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int and n :: int and inv :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "m = prod {x. x > 0 \<and> x < fact 4 \<and> inv (fact 4) x \<noteq> 0}"
and h1 : "n = m mod fact 4"
shows  "n = 1"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int and n :: int and inv :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "m = prod {x. x > 0 \<and> x < fact 4 \<and> inv (fact 4) x \<noteq> 0}"
and h1 : "n = m mod fact 4"
shows  "n = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let $m$ be the product of all integers $x$ such that $x$ is positive, less than $4!$, and the inverse of $x$ modulo $4!$ is nonzero. Let $n$ be the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$. What is $n$? The final answer is $1$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "fact n = prod (upt 1 n)"
and h1 : "m = prod {x \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime x (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int and fact :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "fact n = prod (upt 1 n)"
and h1 : "m = prod {x \<in> {1..<fact 4}. coprime x (fact 4)}"
shows  "m mod fact 4 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the product of all numbers less than $4!$ which are coprime to $4!$. What is the remainder when this product is divided by $4!$? The final answer is $1$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. 1 ≤ n \<and> n < 4! \<and> coprime n (4!)}"
shows  "m mod (4!) = 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. 1 ≤ n \<and> n < 4! \<and> coprime n (4!)}"
shows  "m mod (4!) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ (4 factorial) that are coprime with $4!$. What is the remainder when this product is divided by $4!$? The final answer is $1$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. n \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> [n = 1] (mod fact 4)}"
shows  "[m = 1] (mod fact 4)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $m$ be the product of all positive integers less than $4!$ which are invertible modulo $4!$. Find the remainder when $m$ is divided by $4!$.

(Here $n!$ denotes $1\times\cdots\times n$ for each positive integer $n$.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We compute that $4!=1\times 2\times 3\times 4 = 2^{3}\times 3=24$.
 So we want exactly the numbers in the set $\{1,\ldots,24\}$ which are divisible by neither $2$ nor $3$, since an integer $a$ is invertible modulo $n$ for some positive integer $n$ if and only if $\gcd(a,n)=1$.
 These turn out to be $\{1,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\}$. Then \begin{align} m & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot 13\cdot 17\cdot 19\cdot 23\\ & \equiv 1\cdot 5\cdot 7\cdot 11\cdot (-11)\cdot (-7)\cdot (-5)\cdot (-1)\\
 & \equiv (5\cdot 7\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (35\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (11\cdot 11)^2\\ & \equiv (121)^2\\ & \equiv 1^2\\ & \equiv \boxed{1}\pmod {24} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes m :: int
assumes h0 : "m = prod {n. n \<in> {1..<fact 4} \<and> [n = 1] (mod fact 4)}"
shows  "[m = 1] (mod fact 4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Let $m$ be the product of all numbers $n$ from $1$ to $4!$ (which is $24$), inclusive, such that $n$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $24$. Prove that $m$ is congruent to $1$ modulo $24$.
